title: Ticket #333: Condor_submit fails on filesystem with 64-bit timestamps
description:
An OSG user installed a Compute Element that uses Condor to manage fork jobs. Unfortunately, he was unable to submit jobs from any NFS directory, because condor_submit failed. There is no easy workaround, because Globus uses a user's home directory, and these are on NFS.

The error that is reported looks like this:

% condor_submit submit
Submitting job(s)
ERROR: No such directory: /home/VCELL/aroy

===== Problem 1 (The easy problem) =====
That error message is totally wrong. The directory exists, but Condor thinks it is inaccessible. This is a low severity, low priority thing, but it should be fixed to report a more accurate message.

===== Problem 2 (The hard problem) =====
The error occurs in condor_submit.v6/submit.C in ComputeRootDir(). The code looks like this: 

        if( access(rootdir, F_OK|X_OK) < 0 ) {
            fprintf( stderr, "\nERROR: No such directory: %s\n",
                     rootdir );
            DoCleanup(0,0,NULL);
            exit( 1 );

The access() function call is actually access_euid(), which is our implementation of access() in condor_util_lib. The call fails here: 

    if ((F_OK == 0) || (mode & F_OK)) {
        if (stat(path, &buf) < 0) {
            if( ! errno ) {
                    /* evil!  stat() failed but there's no errno! */
                dprintf( D_ALWAYS, "WARNING: stat() failed, but "
                         "errno is still 0!  Beware of misleading "
                         "error messages\n" );
            }
            return -1;
        }
        already_stated = 1;
    }

stat() fails and provides an errno of 75 (Value too large for defined data type).

This isn't specific to Condor: I wrote a simple program that just calls stat(), and it gets the same error. It only gets this error on NFS, and not for local disks.

I figured that this was a problem with the filesystem, so I passed it back to the user. Fix your filesystem! I cried. Unfortunately, they passed the buck back to me. Here is their response: 

> Ah, but this makes perfect sense...  There is no "problem" with the
> shared file system...
>
> The reason for failing with EOVERFLOW error (errno 75 - Value too
> large...) is 64bit file support of the shared filesystem.  Alain, if you
> compile your program with large file support it will not fail:
>
> [moraru@vdgateway Wed Mar 18 19:01:01 /tmp/stat2] $ gcc
> -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64 -o stat stat.c
> [moraru@vdgateway Wed Mar 18 19:02:13 /tmp/stat2] $ ./stat /home/VCELL/
> name = /home/VCELL/
> rc = 0
> errno = 0
>
> OK - so now you may ask: why did it fail before, even though it didn't
> actually encounter any file > 2GB?
>
> The reason is that our shared file system not only supports large files
> using 64 bits, but also supports 64bit timestamps... This is required
> for proper synching with NTFS file systems (that always use 64bit
> timestamps).  See below a comparison between the timestamps on the
> shared filesystem and the plain vanilla local Linux filesystem:
>
> [moraru@vdgateway Wed Mar 18 19:02:21 /tmp/stat2] $ stat /tmp
>  File: `/tmp'
>  Size: 4096            Blocks: 16         IO Block: 4096   directory
> Device: fd00h/64768d    Inode: 491521      Links: 14
> Access: (1777/drwxrwxrwt)  Uid: (    0/    root)   Gid: (    0/    root)
> Access: 2009-03-18 18:50:41.000000000 -0400
> Modify: 2009-03-18 19:02:13.000000000 -0400
> Change: 2009-03-18 19:02:13.000000000 -0400
> [moraru@vdgateway Wed Mar 18 19:02:41 /tmp/stat2] $ stat /home/VCELL/
>  File: `/home/VCELL/'
>  Size: 1134            Blocks: 34         IO Block: 4096   directory
> Device: 1eh/30d Inode: 4329963743  Links: 45
> Access: (0755/drwxr-xr-x)  Uid: (    0/    root)   Gid: (10000/Domain
> Users)
> Access: 2009-03-18 13:26:34.914135705 -0400
> Modify: 2009-03-18 13:26:34.914135705 -0400
> Change: 2009-03-18 13:26:34.914135705 -0400
>
> So, basically a stat() call to **any** path on the shared filesystem
> will **always** return 64bit timestamps (atime, ctime, mtime) and
> generate EOVERFLOW errors if #define _FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64 was not used.

Indeed, I rebuilt my simple stat() program with -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64, and it worked.

So the claim is that Condor is in the wrong here. Frankly, I find it weird that every program that runs on their filesystem may need to be recompiled. But what can I do?

I talked to Nick about this, and he thinks that if access_euid() used his stat wrapper class, the problem might go away. I don't know if that's the correct solution or not. (Should we have built with this flag?) Also, this problem might be all over Condor: if we fix this call site, will there be others that exhibit the same problem? I don't know.

I'll try to keep access to this site. If I can, I'll be happy to work with someone to test potential bug fixes by deploying a personal (non-root) Condor and running tests.

Thanks, -alain, on behalf of an OSG site.

2009-Mar-19 12:10:16 by matt:
You should check what version of Condor they are running. I had to resolve a similar issue with access() (sadly #define'd to be access_euid()) encountered in the VM Universe. There's a thread on condor-fw about this as well, including information that using Nick's stat wrapper is not an easy solution because it's C++ and the access_euid(), and friends, are C.

Also, globally compiling Condor with 64-bit fs support causes headaches in condor_common.h, so beware.

2009-Mar-23 17:03:46 by roy:
Reappending remarks. I forgot it's a wiki and not a Unix text file. 

> From: "Moraru,Ion" <Moraru@neuron.uchc.edu>
> Date: March 23, 2009 6:42:03 AM CDT
> To: "Alain Roy" <roy@cs.wisc.edu>
> Cc: "Dutton,Jeff" <jdutton@neuron.uchc.edu>, "Abhishek Singh Rana" <rana@fnal.gov>, "Suchandra Thapa" <sthapa@ci.uchicago\
.edu>, <rquick@iupui.edu>, "Chander Sehgal" <cssehgal@fnal.gov>
> Subject: RE: An update on the UCHC_CBG site
>
> Alain, here's more detailed info.
>
> The root cause of the problem is the > 2^32 values of
> Inodes (st_ino) for the files on our shared file system.  I
> initially thought the issue was caused by 64-bit (nanosecond)
> timestamps - but then I remembered that those are being stored as
> 2 separate 32-bit uints: theres one int for each atime, ctime,
> mtime seconds past epoch value, and another one for the
> nanoseconds (hijacked from the former timespec microsec), and
> they have to be put together for the full timestamp (therefore
> these can never cause such problem).
>
> Anyway, the fact is that *all* files, and therefore all
> directories, on the shared file system have large Inode values.
> Why we were not aware of this before, and why this has not been a
> problem before, is due to bug in glibc as follows:
>
> 1. In previous 32bit versions of RHE-based Linux that we've
>    used (Rocks 4.3, SL 4.3 CentOs 4.7), calls to stat() do not
>    fail (as they should) on large Inodes, but instead return a
>    wrong value (truncated 32bit unsigned int + 1).  This is true
>    also for the command line version of stat.  Also, compiling
>    with LFS support gives wrong value.  Booh!
>
> 2. In 64bit versions of RHE-based Linux that we are currently
>    using (Rocks 5, CentOs 5.1), everything is groovy - as it
>    should be.
>
> 3. The only *other* version of Linux that we've used, but only
>    for the OSG site-dedicated cluster and related machines, is
>    32bit CentOS 5, where the call to stat() returns (incorrectly)
>    a truncated 32bit uint, but it does (correctly) return the
>    proper failure error code... - also, BTW, command line stat in
>    this case is correct, it falls back to stat64() and returns
>    the correct 64bit uint value.
>
> Anyway, from the standpoint of Condor: I believe it should be
> considered a bug to some extent.  Condor should, as a 32bit
> install:
> - either declare it does not support LFS
> - or be compiled with proper LFS support and not choke on large values of either st_size, st_ino, or st_blocks
>
> That's it for now.
>
> Ion
